ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Excellent. It is what courses on China should be like!
Yes I would. It gives the student a good understanding of Chinese politics and foreign relations posture.

Overall this was a very interesting, relaxed seminar course on current topics related to China's international relations. The discussion was always stimulating, mainly because of the other students in it. I would recommend this course to another student, though I think how well the class goes would depend to a large degree on the other students in it.

It is a good course that surveys the various issues concerning China's IR. However, be prepared to play a major role in directing the discussion because the vast scope of the course might potentially result in a less focused discussion.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: This course provided me with the theoretical foundation I needed to move forward on my research and provided invaluable opportunities to see how well key IR concepts and theories apply to China and Asia.

I am writing my thesis on recent Chinese economic activities in Africa and this course provided a new background for me on the IR philosophies grounding Chinese behavior, which was very useful. I also benefitted from the discussions on China in Africa that occasionally arose during class sessions.
